questions.text: A 50-year-old farmer from a rural area near Lucknow presents with jaundice and an enlarged liver. He reports consuming homemade grains stored in a damp area. Laboratory tests reveal elevated liver enzymes, and a suspicion of hepatic carcinoma is raised. Given the patient's history and presentation, exposure to which of the following mycotoxins is most concerning?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aspergillus flavus

 

Option A:

 

Aspergillus flavus is known to produce aflatoxins, potent mycotoxins that can contaminate grains stored in damp conditions. Aflatoxins are hepatotoxic and have been implicated in hepatic carcinoma, particularly in the developing world where grain storage conditions can be suboptimal.

 

Figure 1                                                           Figure 2

 

Figure 1: On SDA - yellow at first but quickly becoming bright to dark yellow-green with age. 

On LPCB - Conidial heads are typically radiate, later splitting to form loose columns (mostly 300-400 µm in diameter), biseriate 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Aspergillus niger, while also a species of Aspergillus, is not typically associated with aflatoxin production.

 

  

Figure: On SDA -dense layer of dark-brown to black conidial heads

 

On LPCB- Conidial heads are large (up to 3 mm by 15 to 20 µm in diameter), globose, dark brown, conidiophore stipes are smooth-walled, hyaline or turning dark towards the vesicle.

 

Option C. Candida does not produce aflatoxins.

 

Option D. Cryptococcus and Nocardia are not known for producing aflatoxins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspergillus flavus as the source of aflatoxin production and recognize the clinical manifestations of aflatoxin exposure, which include hepatotoxicity and an increased risk of liver carcinoma.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p573, 2/e p598

questions.text: A laboratory technician is examining a specimen from a patient with a suspected actinomycetoma. When observing the granules under the microscope, which color is most commonly associated with actinomycetes infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Yellow

 

Option B:

 

Actinomycetoma, an infection caused by actinomycetes, is typically characterized by the presence of yellow to white granules in pus or tissue samples from the infected area. These granules, which are aggregates of the causative organisms, are a distinctive feature and aid in the diagnosis of actinomycetoma. The color and appearance of these granules under the microscope are key diagnostic criteria, distinguishing actinomycetoma from other similar infections, such as eumycetoma, which produces differently colored granules.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Black granules are more characteristic of eumycetoma, a fungal mycetoma.

 

Option C. Blue granules are not typically associated with actinomycetoma.

 

Option D. White granules can be seen in actinomycetoma, but yellow granules are more frequently observed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p559, 2/e p583, Jagdish Chander 3/e p150

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to a tertiary care center in Kolkata with signs and symptoms of meningitis. Given his advanced HIV infection, cryptococcal meningitis is high on the differential. Which of the following is the most sensitive and rapid test for the diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Latex Agglutination

 

Option D:

 

The latex agglutination test detects cryptococcal capsular polysaccharide antigen in CSF and is both sensitive and rapid, making it the preferred initial test for the diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis, especially in resource-limited settings.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Culture on SDA is sensitive but not rapid.

 

Option B. Culture on Bird Seed Agar is used for identification and differentiation of Cryptococcus neoformans due to the production of melanin but is slower than latex agglutination.

 

Option C. India Ink is a rapid test but is subjective, and less sensitive than latex agglutination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most sensitive and rapid diagnostic tests for cryptococcal meningitis in HIV-positive patients is latex agglutination test on CSF samples.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p569, 2/e p594

questions.text: A 60-year-old man who is an avid gardener in the Mississippi River Valley presents with a chronic cough, night sweats, and weight loss. A chest X-ray shows diffuse reticulonodular infiltrates. He undergoes a bronchoalveolar lavage, and the fluid shows macrophages filled with intracellular, oval yeast cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Histoplasmosis

 

Option C:

 

Histoplasmosis, caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, is endemic to the Mississippi River Valley and presents with pulmonary symptoms, including a chronic cough and diffuse infiltrates on imaging. The intracellular, oval yeast cells within macrophages on bronchoalveolar lavage fluid are characteristic of this infection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aspergillosis, caused by Aspergillus species, typically presents with septate hyphae in immunocompromised patients and is not associated with the described histopathology.

 

Option B. Blastomycosis, caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis, can present with similar symptoms but is characterized by broad-based budding yeast on microscopy.

 

Option D. Sporotrichosis, caused by Sporothrix schenckii, is typically associated with cutaneous nodules along lymphatic distribution following trauma with plant material and would not show intracellular yeasts on a lung lavage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Histoplasmosis - The intracellular, oval yeast cells within macrophages on bronchoalveolar lavage fluid are characteristic of this infection. 

 

 

Aspergillosis - presents with septate hyphae in immunocompromised patients. 

 

Blastomycosis - characterized by broad-based budding yeast on microscopy. 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1st e/p550, 2/e p574

questions.text: A pathologist receives a lung biopsy from a 38-year-old man with suspected fungal pneumonia. Which stain would be most appropriate to use first to identify potential fungal elements within the tissue?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gomori’s methenamine silver stain

 

Option D:

 

Gomori’s methenamine silver stain is a broad-spectrum fungal stain that is highly sensitive for the presence of fungal organisms due to its ability to bind to the fungal cell walls, making it the preferred initial stain for suspected fungal infections.

 

It is preferred for fungal visualization due to its ability to bind to components of the fungal cell wall.

 

 

Figure: Cysts of P.jerovicii on Gomori Methamine stain

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. PAS stain can also highlight fungal elements but is less specific than Gomori’s methenamine silver stain.

 

 

Figure: PAS stain showing numerous Oblique branching ,aseptate hyphae, ribbon like

 

Option B. Von Kossa stain is used for the detection of calcium, not fungi.

 

 

Figure: Von Kossa stain, showing black calcium deposits

 

Option C. Mucicarmine stain is specifically used for the identification of Cryptococcus species by staining the mucopolysaccharide capsule.

 

 

Figure: Mucicarmins stain showing Cryptococcosis of Lung

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gomori’s methenamine silver stain is the first choice for broad fungal visualization.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1 e/p 551, 2e/ p575

questions.text: A dermatologist is reviewing treatment options for a patient with tinea cruris and tinea corporis who has had limited response to multiple over-the-counter antifungal treatments. Considering recent clinical guidelines and resistance patterns, which antifungal agent is least likely to be recommended due to concerns of resistance and decreased efficacy for these conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Griseofulvin

 

Option A:

 

Griseofulvin has fallen out of favor for the treatment of tinea infections due to emerging resistance and the availability of more effective agents. It has been increasingly replaced by other oral antifungals with fewer resistance issues and better efficacy profiles.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Terbinafine is still commonly prescribed for tinea infections and has a lower resistance rate compared to griseofulvin.

 

Option C. Itraconazole is an effective treatment for a broad range of fungal infections, including tinea cruris and tinea corporis.

 

Option D. Voriconazole is typically used for more severe systemic fungal infections and not commonly prescribed for tinea infections; however, it has not been specifically recommended against due to resistance concerns for these conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p582

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a recurrent, inflammatory dermal and subcutaneous infection characterized by granulomatous nodules on her legs. She has a history of minor trauma to the area while gardening. A fungal culture grows a dermatophyte known to cause deep dermal infection when introduced via cutaneous injury. Which dermatophyte is most commonly associated with this type of granulomatous infection, often referred to as Majocchi's granuloma?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trichophyton rubrum

 

Option A:

 

Trichophyton rubrum is the most common cause of Majocchi's granuloma, a deep fungal infection of the skin that can occur when dermatophytes are introduced into the dermis, often through a minor injury.

 

 

Figure: Trichophyton rubrum: (a) SDA-wine red pigmentation on reverse side. (b) LPCB mount: arrow showing teardrop-shaped microconidia. LPCB, lactophenol cotton blue staining; SDA, Sabouraud dextrose agar.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Epidermophyton is a genus of dermatophytes but is less commonly associated with Majocchi's granuloma.

 

 

Figure : Epidermatophyton flocculosum

 

Option C. Microsporum canis primarily causes tinea capitis and is a less common cause of Majocchi's granuloma.

 

 

Figure: Microsporum Canis on SDA and LPCB mount- Note the “spiny macroconidia”

 

Option D. Trichophyton mentagrophytes can cause Majocchi's granuloma, but it is not as commonly associated with it as Trichophyton rubrum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p555, 2/e p579, Jagdish Chandra’s Mycology 3/e p66

choices.text: May present as a boggy swelling
Most commonly occurs in elderly
May present as black dot
Caused by Trichophyton and Microsporum but not by Epidermophyton

questions.text: A clinician is reviewing the characteristics of Tinea capitis. Which of the following statements is NOT correct regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Most commonly occurs in elderly

 

Option B:

 

Tinea capitis is a fungal infection of the scalp that primarily affects children, not the elderly.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tinea capitis can present as a boggy swelling known as kerion.

 

 

Option C. The 'black dot' pattern occurs when hairs break off at the scalp surface due to fungal invasion.

 

Option D. Tinea capitis is indeed caused by Trichophyton and Microsporum species; Epidermophyton typically does not cause this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tinea capitis -  The condition most commonly affects children and can have various presentations, including the kerion and black dot pattern, but it is not typically seen in the elderly.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p555, 2/e p579

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl presents with scalp lesions and hair loss. She has a pet cat at home that has been scratching itself frequently. A skin scraping of the lesion demonstrates ectothrix invasion of the hair shaft. Which of the following Trichophyton species is known for being zoophilic and is the most likely cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) T. mentagrophytes

 

Option D:

 

T. mentagrophytes is a zoophilic fungus commonly transmitted to humans from animals such as cats and is known to cause tinea capitis with ectothrix invasion of the hair shaft.

 

  

 

Figure: Microconidia and macroconidia of T. mentagrophyte.

 

 

Figure: Chlamydospores and hyphal spirals in T. mentrogrophyte.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. T. tonsurans is an anthropophilic species and a common cause of tinea capitis in humans but is less commonly contracted from animals.

 

Option B. T. violaceum is also an anthropophilic fungus and primarily causes tinea capitis in humans.

 

Option C. T. schoenleinii causes favus, a severe form of tinea capitis, but is not zoophilic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p555, 2/e p579, Jagdish Chander 3/e p135

questions.text: A pediatrician suspects a fungal infection in a child with hypopigmented, scaly lesions on the skin. To assist in the diagnosis, which of the following conditions would most appropriately be evaluated using a Wood's lamp examination?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pityriasis versicolor

 

Option B:

 

Pityriasis versicolor, caused by Malassezia species, characteristically fluoresces under Wood's lamp examination due to the presence of certain metabolites produced by the yeast.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tinea pedis, caused by dermatophytes, typically does not fluoresce under Wood's lamp.

 

Option C. Sporotrichosis, a subcutaneous mycosis, does not fluoresce under Wood's lamp.

 

Option D. Vitiligo, an autoimmune condition resulting in loss of skin pigmentation, will fluoresce under Wood's lamp, but it is not a fungal infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wood's lamp helps in diagnosing certain fungal infections, such as pityriasis versicolor, which exhibit fluorescence due to metabolites produced by the pathogen.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p557, 2/e p580, Jagdish Chander 3/e p135

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with chronic, localized swelling on her arm with draining sinuses that exude yellow-black grains. Histopathological examination of the grains is most likely to reveal which of the following fungal infections?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mycetoma

 

Option B:

 

Mycetoma is characterized by chronic infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue, leading to tumefaction, draining sinuses, and discharge that contains granules, which can be yellow-black in color.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mucormycosis typically presents as an acute, rapidly progressive infection, particularly in immunocompromised patients, and does not produce granules.

 

Option C. Aspergillosis may produce a variety of clinical syndromes, but it does not typically manifest as chronic subcutaneous infection with draining sinuses and granules.

 

Option D. Rhinosporidiosis is associated with polypoid lesions, primarily affecting mucous membranes, not with subcutaneous granules.

Educational Objective:

Mycetoma -  This is distinctive due to its chronic course, the formation of sinuses, and the presence of colored granules in the discharge, which aids in the diagnosis.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p559, 2/e p583

questions.text: A 55-year-old gardener presents with a chronic ulcer on his forearm that has nodular lesions ascending along the lymphatics. Which pathogen is most commonly associated with this sporotrichoid pattern of lymphocutaneous infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sporothrix schenckii

 

Option A:

 

Sporothrix schenckii, a dimorphic fungus, is the causative agent of sporotrichosis, which commonly presents as a nodular lesion at the site of inoculation and can spread along lymphatic channels, a pattern known as sporotrichoid spread.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Fish tank granuloma is caused by Mycobacterium marinum and typically presents with granulomatous lesions, but not the classic sporotrichoid pattern.

 

Option C. Erysipelas is an acute infection caused by Streptococcus pyogenes, presenting with well-demarcated, raised erythema, not a sporotrichoid pattern.

 

Option. D. Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis, characterized by chronic, progressive skin lesions but not a sporotrichoid pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical pattern of lymphocutaneous spread in sporotrichosis and identify Sporothrix schenckii as the causative agent.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p283, 560, 2/e p584

questions.text: A patient with a chronic cutaneous infection presents with hard, black nodules in the tissue. Biopsy shows sclerotic bodies, also known as Medlar bodies. Which of the following infections is associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chromoblastomycosis

 

Option D:

 

Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic subcutaneous condition characterized by slow-growing lesions caused by darkly pigmented fungi known as dematiaceous or phaeoid fungi. These fungi produce distinct structures called sclerotic bodies.

 

  • Causative Agents: Chromoblastomycosis is caused by fungi such as Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Phialophora verrucosa, Cladosporium carrionii, and Rhinocladiella aquaspersa.
  • Types of Lesions: The condition presents with various types of lesions, including verrucose (the most common), crusted, ulcerative, and nodular.
  • Sclerotic Bodies: Sclerotic bodies are a hallmark feature, characterized by thick-walled round cells (5–12 μm in size) with multiple internal transverse septa. They are also known as Medlar bodies or muriform cells.
  • Treatment: Treatment involves surgical removal of the lesion (cryosurgery or laser therapy) followed by antifungal medications, typically itraconazole.

 

 

Figure: Sclerotic bodies, also known as Medlar bodies

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rhinosporidiosis is caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and typically presents with nasal polyps, not sclerotic bodies.

 

Option B. Histoplasmosis is characterized by small intracellular yeasts within macrophages, not by sclerotic bodies.

 

Option C. Coccidioidomycosis is associated with spherules filled with endospores, not sclerotic bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic skin infection caused by dematiaceous (pigmented) fungi and is characterized by the presence of sclerotic bodies in tissue samples.

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p561, 2/e p585, Jagdish Chander 3/e p178

questions.text: In an outpatient clinic in Delhi, a 40-year-old immunocompromised man presents with symptoms of fever, cough, and chest pain. A chest CT shows a single pulmonary nodule, and bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) is performed. A fungal assay is considered as part of the diagnostic workup. For which of the following pathogens is a fungal assay not typically used?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pneumocystis jirovecii

 

Option D:

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is diagnosed using specific stains (such as Gomori's methenamine silver or toluidine blue O) or PCR-based assays, rather than traditional fungal cultures. Pneumocystis does not readily grow on standard fungal media, making direct visualization or molecular methods preferred.

Cysts resemble black colored crushed ping-pong balls, against the green background 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aspergillus species are readily cultured on fungal media and can be identified with fungal assays.

 

Option B. Candida species grow well on standard culture media and are easily identifiable with routine fungal assays.

 

Option C. Cryptococcus species can be cultured on standard media and also identified with specific tests like India ink staining or cryptococcal antigen testing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii requires specialized diagnostic techniques (such as Gomori's methenamine silver or toluidine blue O) or PCR-based assays, different from traditional fungal cultures.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1st e/p568, 2/e p592,594,597

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus presents with high-grade fever, chills, and visual disturbances. Blood cultures are taken, and empirical antifungal therapy is initiated. Laboratory reports later reveal positive (1,3)-β-D-Glucan. Which of the following infections is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Invasive candidiasis

 

Option B:

 

The (1,3)-β-D-Glucan test is a biomarker that is positive in a variety of fungal infections but is particularly useful in diagnosing invasive candidiasis. This test is part of a diagnostic workup for patients suspected of having systemic fungal infections, especially in the context of risk factors like uncontrolled diabetes.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rhinosporidiosis is caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, which is not detected by the (1,3)-β-D-Glucan test.

 

Option C. Mucormycosis, caused by Mucorales fungi, also does not typically result in a positive (1,3)-β-D-Glucan test.

 

Option D. Cryptococcal meningitis, caused by Cryptococcus neoformans, is more specifically diagnosed with cryptococcal antigen testing rather than (1,3)-β-D-Glucan.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The (1,3)-β-D-Glucan test in the diagnosis of invasive fungal infections, particularly invasive candidiasis, and to differentiate it from other fungal diseases that do not elevate this biomarker.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p568, 2/e p592

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with HIV presents to a clinic in Mumbai with a 10-day history of cough. His CD4 count is low, and he has not been on antiretroviral therapy. Sputum culture on Sabouraud dextrose agar (SDA) reveals broad-based budding yeasts. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blastomycosis

 

Option B:

 

The sputum culture showing broad-based budding yeasts is characteristic of Blastomyces dermatitidis. Although traditionally not common in India, there have been case reports of blastomycosis in the Indian subcontinent. The broad-based budding is a key feature distinguishing Blastomyces from other fungi.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Histoplasma capsulatum typically shows narrow-based budding and is more associated with intracellular organisms in macrophages.

 

Option C. Coccidioidomycosis is endemic to the Southwestern United States and parts of Central and South America, not India, and would show spherules with endospores in culture.

 

Option D. Paracoccidioidomycosis is endemic to South America and presents with multiple budding yeast cells, showing mickey mouse or pilots wheel appearance which is not described in this case.

 

 

Figure: Paracoccidioidomycosis. A. Schematic representation of mycelial and yeast forms; B. Methenamine silver staining shows yeast from (pilot wheel appearance)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sputum culture showing broad-based budding yeasts is characteristic of Blastomyces dermatitidis.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e, p588

questions.text: A 32-year-old otherwise healthy woman presents to a primary health center in Bengaluru with complaints of persistent white patches on her tongue and buccal mucosa. (shown in figure) She denies any associated pain or difficulty swallowing. Examination reveals curd-like plaques that are easily scraped off, revealing a mildly erythematous base. No lymphadenopathy is noted. What is the most common fungal infection in non-HIV-infected (immunocompetent) individuals that matches this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Candida

 

Option A:

 

Candida species, particularly Candida albicans, are the most common cause of fungal infections in immunocompetent individuals, presenting as oral thrush with white patches on mucosal surfaces that can be scraped off. This condition is frequently seen in the general population and can occur in individuals with no underlying health issues, although it is more common in those taking antibiotics or with altered local oral environments.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Cryptococcus generally affects immunocompromised individuals and is more commonly associated with meningitis rather than oral thrush.

 

Option C. Mucor (Mucormycosis) is a rapidly progressing fungal infection that occurs mostly in immunocompromised individuals and presents with rhinocerebral, pulmonary, cutaneous, or disseminated disease.

 

Option D. Aspergillus also typically does not present as oral thrush in immunocompetent individuals; it can cause invasive infections primarily in those with weakened immune systems or lung diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Candida as the most common cause of fungal infections presenting as oral thrush in immunocompetent individuals.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p568, 2/e p590, Ananthanarayan 9/e p611, 8/e p607

questions.text: A 32-year-old female with advanced HIV presents with a one-month history of progressive dyspnea on exertion, nonproductive cough, and fever. She has not been adherent to antiretroviral therapy and her CD4 count is 50 cells/μL. A chest CT shows bilateral interstitial infiltrates. Bronchoalveolar lavage is performed and silver stain shows cup-shaped organisms. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neumocystis jirovecii

 

Option B:

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP) is a common opportunistic infection in patients with severe immunosuppression, especially in those with HIV/AIDS and a CD4 count below 200 cells/μL. The cup-shaped organisms (Ping pong ball appearance) on silver stain of the bronchoalveolar lavage fluid are indicative of PJP.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cryptococcus neoformans typically causes meningitis in immunocompromised patients and would be visualized as encapsulated yeasts in cerebrospinal fluid, not on lung lavage.

 

Option C. Histoplasma capsulatum can cause pulmonary symptoms but would present as intracellular yeast within macrophages on silver staining.

 

Option D. Coccidioides immitis causes pulmonary symptoms and can be seen on silver staining, but it typically forms spherules filled with endospores, not the cup-shaped organisms seen in PJP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia is the most common opportunistic infection in immunocompromised patients like in HIV/AIDS esp. If CD4 count is below 200 cells/μL and show cup-shaped organisms (Ping pong ball appearance) on silver stain of bronchoalveolar lavage.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p550, 2/e p574

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of COPD presents with a chronic cough and a solitary pulmonary nodule on chest imaging. Histopathology from a bronchoscopic biopsy of the nodule shows spherules filled with endospores. Which antifungal agent is most appropriate for the treatment of this patient's infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Itraconazole

 

Option B:

 

The presence of spherules filled with endospores is characteristic of Coccidioides infection. Itraconazole is the treatment of choice for a non-disseminated Coccidioides infection, especially in patients with mild to moderate symptoms

 

 

Figure: Coccidioides A. Spherules (PAS staining); B. Hyphae with arthroconidia (LPCB mount)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fluconazole is used in the treatment of Coccidioides meningitis due to its better penetration into the central nervous system.

 

Option C. Amphotericin B is reserved for severe or disseminated Coccidioides infections or for patients who cannot tolerate azoles.

 

Option D. Caspofungin is an echinocandin that is effective against Candida and Aspergillus species but not the first choice for Coccidioides infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coccidioides infection

While azoles such as itraconazole are first-line for mild to moderate pulmonary infections, amphotericin B is reserved for more severe disease presentations. 

 

Clinical Manifestations –

 

  1. Asymptomatic (60%)
  2. Pulmonary coccidioidomycosis (MC form) - Pneumonia, cavities, pleural effusion or           nodule formation.
  3. Skin lesions (rashes or erythema nodosum)
  4. Arthritis
  5. Disseminated form: Persons with low CMI (HIV with CD4+ T cell count <250/ µL) are at higher risk. Common sites are skin, bone, joints, soft tissues, and meninges.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1st e/p550, 2/e p574

questions.text: A researcher is studying a fungal pathogen under the microscope. Which stain is most likely to demonstrate the fungal cell walls and aid in the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Silver methenamine stain

 

Option B:

 

Silver methenamine stain is a special stain used to highlight fungal organisms in tissue sections due to its affinity for fungal cell wall components.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.  Masson trichrome stain is primarily used for connective tissue and muscle fibers.

 

Option C. Alizarin red stain is used to identify calcium deposits in tissue.

 

Option D. Congo red stain is commonly used for the detection of amyloid proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Silver methenamine stain is preferred for fungal visualization due to its ability to bind to components of the fungal cell wall. It is the first choice for broad fungal visualization.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p551, 2/e p575

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with intermittent fever, headaches, and muscle aches. After a detailed history, it is revealed that he recently returned from a trip to a sub-Saharan African country. A blood smear reveals the presence of trypanosomes. The most likely vector responsible for transmitting the pathogen in this case is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tsetse fly

 

Option B:

 

The Tsetse fly is the correct answer because it is the vector responsible for transmitting Trypanosoma brucei, the causative agent of African trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness). This aligns with the patient's symptoms and travel history. The Tsetse fly is unique among vectors as it gives birth to a single larva at a time.

 

 

Life cycle

 

 

Figure: Trypomastigote form of T. brucei in peripheral blood smear examination (Giemsa stain): A. Thin smear; B. Thick smear

 

Explanation:

 

Option A) Anopheles mosquito: Incorrect as it is the vector for malaria, caused by Plasmodium species, not trypanosomiasis.

 

Option C) Aedes mosquito: Incorrect because it is known for transmitting diseases like dengue, Zika, and yellow fever, not African trypanosomiasis.

 

Option D) Flea: Incorrect as fleas are vectors for diseases like plague and typhus, not African trypanosomiasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The vector responsible for transmitting Trypanosoma brucei, the causative agent of African trypanosomiasis. Female tsetse mate just once. After 7–9 days she produces a single egg which develops into a larva within her uterus.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Parasitology 2/e, p260, Wikipedia

choices.text: Body at an angle when resting

questions.text: A public health officer is investigating a recent increase in malaria cases in a rural area. Which of the following characteristics is most specific to the Anopheles mosquito, the primary vector for malaria?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Body at an angle when resting

 

Option C:

 

The Anopheles mosquito, known for transmitting malaria, is characterized by its unique resting position where its body forms an angle with the surface. This distinctive posture differentiates it from other mosquito species.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A) Spots on wings: Incorrect, as this is not a specific characteristic of the Anopheles mosquito.

 

Option B) Lay eggs in cluster: Incorrect, many mosquito species lay eggs in clusters, not specific to Anopheles.

 

Option D) Palpi as long as proboscis: Incorrect, while this is true for the Anopheles mosquito, it is not as distinctive as the body angle for identification purposes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Anopheles mosquito, identified by a slender body resting at an angle to the surface, features dark spots on wings, outstretched hind legs, and a proboscis aligned in a straight line with the body. Both sexes have maxillary palpi as long as the proboscis, a blunt abdomen tip, and specific peak biting hours, varying in indoor or outdoor preferences. Notable species like A. culicifacies and A. stephensi are vectors of malaria.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Parasitology 1/e p316

questions.text: In a rural clinic, a patient presents with gastrointestinal symptoms and a history of walking barefoot in a region endemic for various parasites. Which of the following parasites is known to have the ability to penetrate intact human skin?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Strongyloides

 

Option C:

 

Strongyloides stercoralis, the causative agent of strongyloidiasis, is known for its ability to penetrate intact human skin, which is the usual route of infection in humans.

 

 

Figure: Lifecycle of Strongyloides stercoralis

 

Explanation:

 

Option A) Giardia: Incorrect, as Giardia lamblia is transmitted through contaminated water, not through skin penetration.

 

Option B) Whipworm: Incorrect, as Trichuris trichiura (whipworm) is transmitted through ingestion of eggs, not skin penetration.

 

Option D) Trichinella: Incorrect, as Trichinella spiralis is acquired by ingesting undercooked meat, not through skin penetration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The unique transmission route of Strongyloides stercoralis, which can penetrate intact human skin, an important factor in its diagnosis and prevention,distinct from the other organisms listed.

 

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Parasitology, 1/e p5, 2/e p4

questions.text: During a lecture on parasitology, a medical student asks about the longest worm known to infect humans. Which of the following is the correct answer?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Taenia saginata

 

Option B:

 

Taenia saginata, commonly known as the beef tapeworm, is the longest worm that can infect humans, reaching lengths of up to 25 meters.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A) Taenia solium: Incorrect, although it is a long tapeworm, it is generally shorter than Taenia saginata. 

 

  • T. solium- adult worm measures 2–3 meters in length
  • T. saginata- adult worm measures 5–10 meters in length

 

Option C) Hookworm: Incorrect, hookworms are much smaller than both Taenia species. adult worm measures 12 cm

 

Option D) Ascaris lumbricoides: Incorrect, while large, it does not reach the length of Taenia saginata. adult worm 20–30 cm

 

Educational Objective:

 

The longest worm that can infect humans is Taenia saginata, also known as the beef tapeworm. It is known for its substantial length, capable of reaching up to 25 meters. 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Parasitology 1/e p167, 2/e p138

questions.text: A medical student is studying the life cycles of various parasites. Which of the following parasites has a simple life cycle without intermediate hosts?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Giardia lamblia

 

Option D:

 

Giardia lamblia has a simple life cycle involving only humans or other mammals as hosts, with no intermediate hosts required.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A) Ascaris lumbricoides: Incorrect, although it does not require an intermediate host, its life cycle is not as simple as Giardia's.

 

Option B) Taenia solium: Incorrect, requires an intermediate host (pigs).

 

Option C) Toxoplasma gondii: Incorrect, involves intermediate hosts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parasites with a direct/simple life cycle:

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Parasitology 1/e p6-7, 2/e p5

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms suggestive of a parasitic infection acquired through the consumption of raw fish. Which of the following parasites, known to use fish as an intermediate host, is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diphyllobothrium latum

 

Option A:

 

Diphyllobothrium latum, also known as the fish tapeworm, uses fish as an intermediate host. Infection occurs through the consumption of raw or undercooked infected fish.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B) Clonorchis sinensis: Incorrect, although it also uses fish as an intermediate host, D. latum is more directly associated with raw fish consumption.

 

Option C) Hymenolepis diminuta: Incorrect, does not use fish as an intermediate host.

 

Option D) Hymenolepis nana: Incorrect, does not use fish as an intermediate host.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parasites with an indirect/complex life cycle that require one definitive host and two intermediate hosts

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry's Essentials of Medical Parasitology 1/e p163, 207,2/e p129,165

questions.text: In a tropical medicine lecture, the topic of mosquito-borne diseases is being discussed. Which of the following diseases is primarily transmitted by the Culex mosquito?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Japanese Encephalitis (JE)

 

Option D:

 

Japanese Encephalitis is predominantly transmitted by the Culex mosquito, especially in rural and agricultural areas.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A) Malaria: Incorrect, transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes.

 

Option B) Chikungunya: Chikungunya is transmitted by Aedes ageypti or aedes albopictus..

 

Option C) Dengue: Incorrect, transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Disease predominantly transmitted by the Culex mosquito is Japanese Encephalitis (JE), especially in rural and agricultural areas where these mosquitoes are common. 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Parasitology 1/e p315, 2/e p259

questions.text: Which of the following parasites uses pigs as a reservoir?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Taenia solium

 

Option A:

Taenia solium, also known as the pork tapeworm, uses pigs as an intermediate host, making them a key reservoir for the parasite.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B) Taenia saginata: Incorrect, uses cattle as an intermediate host.

 

Option C) Trichinella spiralis: Incorrect, although associated with pigs, it is not considered a reservoir in the same way as Taenia solium.

 

Option D) Ancylostoma: Incorrect, not associated with pigs as a reservoir.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

*Man acts as definitive host for all 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Parasitology 1/e p6-7, 2/e p5

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea. He recently returned from a trip to a tropical country. On examination, his stool sample reveals trophozoites with ingested red blood cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Entamoeba histolytica

 

Option B:

 

Entamoeba histolytica is the correct diagnosis. This organism is known to cause dysentery characterized by bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. The presence of trophozoites with ingested red blood cells in the stool is a classic finding for Entamoeba histolytica infection.

 

 

Figure: Cyst of E. histolytica: A. Saline mount; B. Iodine mount; and C. Trichrome stained smear.

 

 

Figure: Entamoeba histolytica trophozoites: A. Saline mount; B and C. Trichrome stain, note the single nucleus (black arrow), RBCs (red arrow) and ectoplasm and endoplasm (orange arrows); D. Trophozoites in colon tissue stained with H&E

 

Explanation:

 

Option A) Giardia lamblia: Incorrect, as it usually causes non-bloody diarrhea and does not ingest red blood cells.

 

 

Figure: Cysts of Giardia lamblia: A. Saline mount; B. Iodine mount; C. Trichrome stain; D. Direct immunofluorescence assay (yellow arrow indicates Giardia cyst and white arrow indicates oocyst of Cryptosporidium)

 

 

Figure: Trophozoites of Giardia lamblia A. Saline mount front view; B. Trichrome stain front view; C. Merthiolate iodine formalin (MIF) stain lateral view (spoon shape D); D. Giemsa-stained mucosal imprint (front view)

 

Option C) Salmonella Typhi: Incorrect, as it typically causes typhoid fever with systemic symptoms rather than dysentery.

 

Option D) Clostridium perfringens: Incorrect, as it typically causes food poisoning with watery diarrhea but not dysentery with ingested red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entamoeba histolytica - This organism is specifically known for causing dysentery and trophozoites with ingestion of red blood cells is a classic indication of its infection. 

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med Parasitology 1/e p27, 2e/p19

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with a history of dysentery. A colonoscopic examination is most likely to reveal lesions indicative of amoebiasis in which part of colon?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ileocecal colon

 

Option D: 

 

Amoebiasis most commonly affects the Ileocecal region. This area is frequently involved in amoebic colitis causing flask shaped ulcers, presenting with symptoms like dysentery and abdominal pain.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sigmoid colon: Incorrect, as sigmoid colon is the second most common part to be involved.

 

Option B. Transverse colon: Incorrect, as amoebiasis less commonly affects this part.

 

Option C. Ascending colon: Incorrect, although it can be involved, it is not the most common site.

  

Educational Objective:

 

The most common site for Amebiasis is ileocecal region followed by Sigmoid colon or may be generalized involving whole of large intestine. It produces flask shape ulcers in colon

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Parasitology 1/e p28, 2/e p2

questions.text: Among soft contact lens users, which organism is the most common cause of keratitis infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acanthamoeba

 

Option B: 

Acanthamoeba is the most common organism causing keratitis infection in soft contact lens users. It can lead to severe eye infections in these individuals.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A) Naegleria: Incorrect, as Naegleria is not typically associated with contact lens-related keratitis.

 

Option C) Gonococcus: Incorrect, as this bacterium is known for causing gonorrhea but not keratitis.

 

Option D) Staphylococcus aureus: Incorrect, as Staphylococcus aureus can cause eye infections but is not the most common cause in contact lens users.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common organism causing keratitis infection in soft contact lens users is Acanthamoeba.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Parasitology 1/e p44, 2/e p32

questions.text: A previously healthy individual suddenly develops symptoms of acute meningoencephalitis, including severe headache, fever, and altered mental status. Upon further investigation, it is found that the individual had been swimming in a warm freshwater lake recently. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Naegleria

 

Option B:

 

The rapid onset of acute meningoencephalitis in a person who has been swimming in warm freshwater strongly suggests an infection with Naegleria fowleri. This organism, commonly referred to as the "brain-eating amoeba," typically enters the body through the nasal passages during swimming and travels to the brain, causing a severe and often fatal infection known as primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM). Naegleria fowleri is found in warm bodies of freshwater, such as lakes and hot springs, making the patient's recent swimming activity particularly relevant.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A) Acanthamoeba: Incorrect, as Acanthamoeba can cause keratitis and other infections but typically does not lead to acute meningoencephalitis.

 

Option C) Meningococcus: Incorrect, as Neisseria meningitidis (Meningococcus) can cause bacterial meningitis but is not associated with swimming in freshwater.

 

Option D) Balamuthia: Incorrect, as Balamuthia mandrillaris is a rare cause of granulomatous amebic encephalitis, and it is less likely in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Naegleria fowleri infection as the most likely cause of acute meningoencephalitis in an individual with recent history of swimming in warm freshwater.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med Parasitology 1/e p40, 2/e p29

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy presents to the pediatric clinic with a 3-week history of loose, bulky stools and intermittent abdominal pain. His mother mentions that the family recently went camping near a freshwater lake near Manesar, Haryana. Physical examination is unremarkable except for mild abdominal distension. Stool examination is ordered and shows the following finding on direct iodine mount preparation. 

 

 

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical presentation and stool examination findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Giardia lamblia

 

Option B:


Giardia lamblia is a protozoan parasite that causes giardiasis, characterized by loose, bulky stools, abdominal pain, and malabsorption. 

 

Malabsorption: There could be various types which include:

 

  • Malabsorption of fat (steatorrhea: Leads to foul smelling profuse frothy diarrhea.
  • Disaccharidase deficiencies (lactate, xylose): Leading to lactose intolerance.
  • Malabsorption of vitamin B12 and folic acid and protein losing enteropathy.

 

The history of camping near freshwater, bulky foul-smelling stools without blood (secondary to the malabsorption caused by Giardia support the diagnosis. Giardiasis is commonly contracted from contaminated water.

 

Other points about Giardia lamblia: 

 

  • Habitat: Mucosa of duodenum and upper ileum of man.
  • Morphology: 2 forms
    • Trophozoites
      • Front view: Tear-drop shaped/racket shaped/piriform shaped,
      • Lateral view: sickle/ spoon shaped
      • Shows falling leaf like motility, 10–20 μm in length and 5–15 μm in width.
      •  It has 2 nuclei, 4 pairs of flagella, 2 axonemes, 2 parabasal body and two Ventral sucking disk
    •  Cyst
      • Mature cyst is oval, 11–14 μm in length and 7–10 μm in width, consists of 4 nuclei and axonemes. Cysts are passed in feces.

 

 

Giardia Lamblia (schematic diagram): A. Trophozoite front view; B. Trophozoite lateral view; C. Cyst

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A) Entamoeba histolytica usually presents with dysentery (bloody diarrhea), which is not described in this case.

 

Option C) Cryptosporidium infection can cause similar symptoms but is more commonly associated with immunocompromised patients.

 

Option D) E. coli infection typically presents with a more acute onset of symptoms and often includes fever, which is not mentioned in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:


Giardiasis should be suspected in patients with a history of consuming or being exposed to potentially contaminated freshwater and presenting with chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and malabsorption. The absence of bloody diarrhea helps differentiate it from Entamoeba histolytica infection, while the patient's immune status can help distinguish it from Cryptosporidium. 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Parasitology 1/e p50, 2e/p41

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic with complaints of vaginal discharge, itching, and dysuria for the past week. She reports no recent changes in her sexual partners. On pelvic examination, the cervix appears erythematous with a punctate hemorrhagic appearance.

 

 

The finding of a "strawberry cervix" in this patient is most characteristic of an infection with which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trichomonas vaginalis

 

Option B:


A "strawberry cervix," characterized by erythema and punctate hemorrhages, is a classic finding in Trichomonas vaginalis infection. This protozoan infection presents with vaginal discharge, itching, and sometimes dysuria.

 

Other important points about T.vaginalis

 

  • MC parasitic cause of STI (sexually transmitted infection) and NGU (nongonococcal urethritis)
  • Trophozoite (Infective stage and diagnostic stage) is the only form. No cystic stage. However, pseudocyst forms are seen in culture.  

 

 

Figure: Trophozoite (flagellate D) of Trichomonas vaginalis (schematic diagram)

 

 

Figure: Trichomonas vaginalis trophozoite (Giemsa stain)

 

  • Clinical Disease (IP - 4–28 days)
    •  In men: Asymptomatic or Urethritis, Prostatitis and Cystitis
    •  In women: Asymptomatic or vulvo-vaginitis—Characterized by Profuse vaginal discharge with offensive smell, high pH (> 4.5). Smell gets accentuated by adding 10% KOH (whiff test)
    • Strawberry appearance of vaginal mucosa (Colpitis macularis) seen in 2% of cases
  • Lab Diagnosis - 
    • Microscopy of Vaginal, and urethral discharges: Actively motile (Jerky motility) trophozoites. Its sensitivity is (40–80%) and specificity is up to 100%
    •  Staining: Giemsa and papanicolaou staining or Direct fluorescent antibody (DAF) test and acridine orange fluorescent stain
    • Culture: More sensitive, gold standard e.g. Lash’s cysteine hydrolysate serum media

 

Explanation:

 

Option A) Gardnerella vaginalis is associated with bacterial vaginosis, which typically presents with a white, fishy-smelling discharge but not a strawberry cervix.

 

Option C) Mycoplasma hominis is a potential pathogen in pelvic inflammatory disease but is not associated with the strawberry cervix appearance.

 

Option D) Neisseria gonorrhea can cause cervicitis but does not typically present with the strawberry cervix appearance.

 

Educational Objective:


"Strawberry cervix" as a key clinical sign of Trichomonas vaginalis infection. The distinctive appearance of the cervix in combination with symptoms of vaginal discharge and itching should prompt consideration of this diagnosis. Metronidazole or tinidazole (2 grams, single dose) to both the sexual partners is DOC.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy living in a rural area of India presents with unilateral eyelid swelling, conjunctivitis, and fever. He has no significant past medical history. His family reports an increase in insects in their home, especially at night. Physical examination reveals unilateral periorbital swelling.

 

 

This condition is associated most commonly with which organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Trypanosomiasis

 

Option A:


Romana sign, characterized by unilateral periorbital swelling and conjunctivitis, is a classic sign of acute Chagas disease, which is caused by the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma cruzi. Though not endemic to India, cases can be seen in individuals with a travel history to endemic areas in Latin America.

 

Life cycle

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B) Toxoplasmosis does not typically present with Romana sign.

 

Option C) Piroplasmosis, caused by Babesia species, presents with fever and hemolytic anemia but not with Romana sign.

 

Option D) Leishmaniasis can cause cutaneous or visceral symptoms, but Romana sign is not a feature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trypanosomiasis. Romana sign, marked by unilateral periorbital swelling and conjunctivitis, indicates acute Chagas disease from Trypanosoma cruzi. It's rare in India but seen in those who've visited endemic Latin American regions. 

 

Toxoplasmosis, Piroplasmosis (Babesia species), and Leishmaniasis don't exhibit Romana sign.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Parasitology/p82, 2e/p64.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man, who recently returned from a trip to Africa where he swam in freshwater lakes, presents with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and hematuria. His symptoms are suggestive of an infection acquired through water contact. Identifying the parasite whose infective form is cercariae is important for his diagnosis and treatment:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Schistosoma haematobium

 

Option A:

 

Schistosoma haematobium's infective form is cercariae, which are released by freshwater snails and can penetrate human skin during contact with contaminated water. The patient's symptoms and exposure history are consistent with schistosomiasis, a disease caused by Schistosoma haematobium.

 

Life cycle

 

 

 

Figure: S. haematobium

 

Explanation:

 

Option B) Paragonimus westermani: The infective form is metacercariae, not cercariae.

 

Option C) Fasciola hepatica: Also has metacercariae as the infective form.

 

Option D) Taenia solium: The infective form is the cysticercus, not cercariae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Schistosoma haematobium - infective form is cercariae.
  • Paragonimus westermani and Fasciola hepatica - Metacercariae as their infective form, 
  • Taenia solium's - infective form is the cysticercus

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Parasitology 1/e p194, 2/e p155

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of intermittent diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss for the past six months. He immigrated from a tropical country two years ago and has no significant past medical history. His physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory investigations reveal eosinophilia. Stool examination shows larva currens. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for his symptoms through a mechanism of autoinfection?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Strongyloides

 

Option B:


Strongyloides stercoralis is a parasitic nematode that causes strongyloidiasis. It can lead to autoinfection, where the parasite's life cycle allows it to multiply within the host, leading to persistent infections, especially in immunocompromised individuals. The clinical presentation of intermittent diarrhea, abdominal pain, weight loss, and eosinophilia, along with the finding of larva currens in stool, is characteristic of strongyloidiasis.

 

Explanation:


Option A. Cystoisospora: typically presents with watery diarrhea in immunocompromised patients. It does not cause autoinfection.


Option C. Giardia: Giardiasis can cause diarrhea and abdominal pain but does not involve autoinfection and is less likely to cause eosinophilia.


Option D. Gnathostoma: It is a nematode causing gnathostomiasis, associated with migratory skin lesions and eosinophilia but does not undergo autoinfection.

 

Educational Objective:


In patients with a history of residence in or travel to tropical regions presenting with gastrointestinal symptoms and eosinophilia, Strongyloides stercoralis should be considered. Strongyloidiasis is unique among intestinal helminths due to its ability to cause autoinfection, leading to persistent infections that can last for decades, particularly in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Parasitology 1/e p5, 2/e p5

choices.text: Monoecious, and the organism is related to parthenogenesis.
Transmitted by intake of contaminated food and water.
Pulmonary pneumonia is caused by the same organism.
The body acquires this infection through filariform larvae.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male with a history of kidney transplantation presents with persistent diarrhea. He mentions recent gardening without gloves, which he has taken up since his retirement. A picture accompanying his case shows active worms in his stool. 

 

 

Considering the worm motility observed and his immunocompromised status, which of the following is the correct statement about the organism causing his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The body acquires this infection through filariform larvae.

 

Option D:


The clinical presentation of diarrhea and the history of kidney transplantation, which implies immunosuppression, along with the observation of active worms in the stool, is indicative of an infection by Strongyloides stercoralis. This organism has a life cycle that includes the penetration of the host skin by filariform larvae, which is a common mode of entry, especially in individuals who have soil contact without proper protection. In immunocompromised patients, this can lead to hyperinfection and potentially lethal dissemination.

 

Larva in stool specimen of a transplant patient with diarrhoea suggestive of larva of Strongyloides

 

  • Strongyloides is dioecious, but exhibits parthenogenesis.

  •  Transmitted by skin penetration of through filariform larvae, not by intake contaminated food and water

  •  Loffler’s pneumonia is caused by Strongyloides stercoralis.

 

Explanation:


Option A. Monoecious organisms and parthenogenesis do not accurately describe Strongyloides, which is dioecious and reproduces through autoinfection.
 

Option B. While Strongyloides can be transmitted through contaminated soil, transmission through food and water is more characteristic of other organisms like Giardia or Cryptosporidium.
 

Option C. Pulmonary pneumonia is typically associated with other orgnasims.  Strongyloides stercoralis. Can be associated with Loeffler’s pneumonia when the worm passes through the lung to complete its cycle

 

Educational Objective:
 

Hyperinfection syndrome: Autoinfection is responsible for maintaining the infection as long as 30–40 years and can cause disseminated infection and hyperinfection syndrome. The underlying cause of hyperinfection syndrome is the repeated autoinfection cycles, which leads to generation of large number of filariform larvae. The larvae penetrate the GIT and migrate to various organs.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Parasitology 2/e p190

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents to the clinic with signs of weakness and pallor. Laboratory investigations reveal a hemoglobin level of 4.8 g/dL. The child's parents report a history of tarry stools. The family lives in a rural area with poor sanitation. Physical examination shows no significant findings except for pallor. Which parasite is most likely responsible for this child's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hookworm

 

Option A:

 

Hookworm infection is a common cause of iron deficiency anemia, especially in children living in areas with poor sanitation. The larvae of hookworms penetrate the skin and eventually reach the intestines, where they attach to the mucosa, causing chronic blood loss leading to iron deficiency anemia. The child's presentation with weakness, severe anemia (Hb <5 g/dL), and history of tarry stools (indicative of gastrointestinal blood loss) align with the clinical manifestation of hookworm infection.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Roundworm: Typically causes intestinal obstruction or malabsorption but not significant blood loss.

 

Option C. Whipworm: Trichuris trichiura (whipworm) can cause dysentery and rectal prolapse but is less likely to cause severe anemia.

 

Option D. Pinworm: Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm) is known for causing perianal itching, especially at night, but is not a cause of significant blood loss or anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a pediatric patient presenting with severe anemia and a history of gastrointestinal blood loss, especially in a setting of poor sanitation, hookworm infection should be considered as a potential cause. 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Parasitology 2/e p196

questions.text: A 55-year-old individual living in a tropical region presents with complaints of eye discomfort, including itching and redness. On examination, small subcutaneous nodules are observed under the skin. The patient is concerned about the eye symptoms and asks if these nodules could be related. Which of the following parasites does NOT cause lymphatic filariasis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Loa loa

 

Option A:

 

Loa loa, also known as the African eye worm, causes subcutaneous nodules and eye symptoms but does not cause lymphatic filariasis. It is important to differentiate between different filarial worms when assessing clinical symptoms.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B) Wuchereria bancrofti - Wuchereria bancrofti is a known cause of lymphatic filariasis.

 

Option C) Brugia malayi - Brugia malayi is another filarial worm that can cause lymphatic filariasis.

 

Option D) Brugia timori - Brugia timori is also a filarial worm associated with lymphatic filariasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wuchereria bancrofti (MC), Brugia malayi, and Brugia timori are all known to cause lymphatic filariasis. 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Parasitology 1/e p263, 2/e p221

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman from Chennai with a CD4 count of 50 cells/mm³ presents with a dry cough and dyspnea. A chest CT scan shows ground-glass opacities. Bronchoalveolar lavage is performed. What is the drug of choice for the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cotrimoxazole

 

Option A:

 

The patient's symptoms and CD4 count are suggestive of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP), for which cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) is the treatment of choice.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Penicillin: This antibiotic is used against bacterial infections and has no activity against fungi like Pneumocystis jirovecii.

 

Option C. Amphotericin B: While amphotericin B is an antifungal agent, it is not the first-line treatment for Pneumocystis pneumonia. It may be used in severe cases or when patients cannot tolerate cotrimoxazole.

 

Option D. Clotrimazole: This is an antifungal medication commonly used for treating fungal infections of the skin, mouth, and vagina, not for systemic infections like Pneumocystis pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia in an HIV/AIDS patient with severe immunosuppression - cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) is the first-line treatment.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p 576, 2/e p601

questions.text: A biopsy from the upper lobe of a patient with suspected fungal infection shows budding yeasts with surrounding clear spaces. Which staining technique is most suitable for visualizing these fungal organisms and their characteristic capsules?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Periodic acid-Schiff (PAS)

 

Option D:

 

The PAS stain is a carbohydrate stain that is particularly useful for identifying fungi because it stains the polysaccharides in fungal cell walls a bright magenta color. This stain would be appropriate for visualizing the capsule of budding yeasts, such as Cryptococcus neoformans.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alizarin red is used for staining calcium and is not specific for fungi.

 

Option B. Verhoeff dye is used for staining elastic fibers and is not suitable for fungi.

 

Option C. Manson’s trichrome is a stain primarily used for detecting parasites, not fungal capsules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PAS stain is ideal for highlighting fungal cell walls and capsules, which are rich in polysaccharides, thus aiding in the diagnosis of fungal infections.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p551, 2/e p575, Jagadish Chander 3/e p518

questions.text: A gardener has multiple vesicles on the hand and multiple eruptions along the lymphatics. Which fungus is most commonly responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sporothrix schenckii

 

Option A:

 

Sporotrichosis, caused by the thermally dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii, is a chronic subcutaneous pyogranulomatous disease with various clinical manifestations:

 

  • Nodulo-ulcerative lesions spreading along lymphatics (painless)
  • Enlarged, suppurative, and indurated lymph nodes
  • Rare clinical types include osteoarticular, pulmonary, and disseminated sporotrichosis.

 

 

Epidemiology: Prevalent in tropical, humid countries like South Africa and India (sub-Himalayan hilly areas). Risk factors include barefoot walking, particularly among farmers and gardeners

 

Laboratory Diagnosis:

 

  • Direct Microscopy with H and E staining reveals cigar-shaped asteroid bodies, characterized by a central basophilic yeast cell surrounded by an eosinophilic mass (Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon).
  • Culture at 25°C produces mycelial form with slender hyphae and flower-like conidia.
  • Culture at 37°C produces yeast form with moist creamy white colonies.
  • Serology: Latex agglutination test detects serum antibodies in extracutaneous cases.
  • Skin test may show delayed hypersensitivity against sporotrichin antigen.

 

Treatment: Itraconazole is the DOC, except for disseminated infection (amphotericin B is DOC).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Cladosporium is not commonly associated with lymphocutaneous lesions.

 

Option C. Histoplasma typically causes pulmonary infections and can cause disseminated disease, but not typically lymphocutaneous lesions.

 

Option D. Candida typically causes mucocutaneous infections and can disseminate, but it does not present with lymphocutaneous sporotrichoid spread.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sporothrix schenckii is the causative agent of sporotrichosis, which can present with lymphocutaneous involvement, particularly following trauma with plant material.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p561, 2/e p584, Jagdish Chander 3/e p163

questions.text: A diabetic patient in India presents with a soft tissue infection characterized by the presence of broad, non-septate hyphae on microscopic examination. Which of the following fungi is most likely responsible for this infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Apophysomyces

 

Option D:

 

Apophysomyces, along with other members of the Mucorales order, is characterized by its broad, ribbon-like, non-septate hyphae. This type of fungus is known to cause mucormycosis, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with uncontrolled diabetes. Mucormycosis is a serious infection that often affects the sinuses, brain, or lungs, but can also manifest in soft tissue infections. The distinct microscopic features of broad, non-septate hyphae are key in identifying Apophysomyces as the causative agent in this case.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Candida: Typically forms pseudohyphae and yeast cells, not broad, non-septate hyphae.

 

 

 

Option B. Aspergillus: Typically has septate hyphae with acute angle branching, not broad, non-septate hyphae.

 

 

Figure: Conidiation of various Aspergillus species. A)  A. fumigatus; B)  A. flavus; C)  A. niger

 

Option C. Penicillium: Not typically associated with invasive infections in humans and has septate hyphae with characteristic conidia.

 

 

Figure: Penicillium species. A. Colonies on SDA; B. Microscopic picture (LPCB mount); C. Schematic microscopic picture

 

Educational Objective:

 

Apophysomyces, along with other members of the Mucorales order, is characterized by broad, ribbon-like, non-septate hyphae. It is an emerging pathogen causing mucormycosis, especially in immunocompromised individuals such as those with uncontrolled diabetes.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p570-71, 2/e p594

choices.text: It is seen only in immunocompromised individuals.
May be associated with pneumatocele formation.

questions.text: In a tertiary care hospital in Kolkata, a clinician is reviewing a presentation on Pneumocystis jirovecii. Which of the following statements about P. jirovecii is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is seen only in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Option A:

 

While P. jirovecii is most common in immunocompromised individuals, it can occasionally be identified in those who are immunocompetent, making statement a false.

Pneumocystis is classified under fungus based on nucleic acid sequence studies:

 

  • Exist in two forms: In environment cysts are found, whereas in human tissues both cysts and trophozoites are found.

  • Cysts are inhaled, carried to the lungs, transformed into trophozoite stage which induces an inflammatory response that leads to recruitment of plasma cells resulting in formation of frothy exudate filling the alveoli. Hence, PcP is also called plasma cell pneumonia.

 

Laboratory Diagnosis:

 

Gomori’s methenamine silver (GMS) staining is the method of choice to demonstrate the cysts of P. jirovecii. The cysts resemble black colored crushed ping-pong balls, against the green background.

 

 

Figure: Cysts of Pneumocystis jirovecii in lung tissue of an AIDS patient (methenamine silver stain) (arrow showing)

 

Treatment: Cotrimoxazole is the DOC for Pneumocystis pneumonia. It is also the recommended drug for primary and secondary prophylaxis in patients with HIV.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Frequently associated with CMV (Cytomegalovirus): Pneumocystis jirovecii infection may coexist with other opportunistic infections in immunocompromised patients, including CMV. 

 

Option C. May be associated with pneumatocele formation: Pneumocystis jirovecii can cause pneumatoceles, which are cystic air spaces that develop in the lung due to the damage caused by the infection. This statement is true and describes one of the possible complications of P. jirovecii pneumonia.

 

Option D. Diagnosed with BAL microscopy: Pneumocystis jirovecii can indeed be diagnosed using induced sputum or BAL microscopy, particularly using special stains such as Gomori methenamine silver or immunofluorescence assays, which can detect the cysts or trophic forms of the organism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The objective is to correct the misconception that Pneumocystis jirovecii is only seen in immunocompromised individuals. While P. jirovecii is a significant cause of pneumonia in the immunocompromised, it can also colonize the lungs of healthy individuals without causing illness. This understanding is important for accurate diagnosis and treatment of Pneumocystis pneumonia, especially in patients with weakened immune systems.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p576, 2/e p600

choices.text: They are sequestered in the spleen
Due to adherence to the capillary endothelium, they are not seen in peripheral blood
Due to antigen-antibody reaction and removal, antibody-dependent cytotoxic killing
They are seen in mosquito blood

questions.text: A medical student is learning about the life cycle of Plasmodium falciparum and its presentation in blood smears. Why are schizont and late trophozoite stages of Plasmodium falciparum not seen in peripheral blood smears?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Due to adherence to the capillary endothelium, they are not seen in peripheral blood

 

Option B:

 

P. falciparum gets sequestrated by adhering to the endothelium of deep vessels. After the ring forms are formed, the remaining part of RBC cycle of P. falciparum occurs in deep vessels (not in peripheral blood. This is the reason why schizont and late trophozoite stages are not seen in peripheral blood smear.

 

 

Figure: A. P. falciparum ring forms such as multiple rings (blue arrow), accole form (red arrow) and head phone-shaped ring form (black arrow); B. Female gametocyte of P. falciparum; C. Male gametocyte of P. falciparum

 

Life cycle of Plasmodium

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. They are sequestered in the spleen – Partially true, but the main reason is adherence to the endothelium.

 

Option C. Due to antigen-antibody reaction – This does not primarily account for their absence in smears.

 

Option D. They are seen in mosquito blood – Not relevant to their absence in human peripheral blood smears.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In P. falciparum infections, schizonts and late trophozoites stick to the capillary endothelium, causing their absence in peripheral blood smears as they are sequestered in organs. Other factors like spleen sequestration and antigen-antibody reactions play lesser roles, and their presence in mosquito blood is unrelated to their absence in human smears.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry's Essentials of Medical Parasitology/p94, 2/e p77

questions.text: A healthcare professional is conducting a training session on blood safety and the risks of transfusion-associated infections, including malaria. Which form of the malaria parasite is responsible for transfusion-associated malaria?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trophozoite

 

Option A:

 

Transfusion-associated malaria is typically caused by the trophozoite form of the parasite. These forms are present in the infected donor's blood and can be transmitted through blood transfusion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Sporozoites – These are the forms injected by mosquitoes, not typically found in transfused blood.

 

Option C. Female gametocyte – Not the primary infective form in transfusions.

 

Option D. Male gametocyte – Like female gametocytes, not the primary infective form in transfusions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Infective form of Plasmodium

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry's Essentials of Medical Parasitology/p101, 2/e p72

questions.text: A 35-year-old male in India presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of high fever, severe headache, and episodes of vomiting. He has recently returned from a rural area with known malaria transmission. On examination, he is febrile (39.5°C, disoriented, and experiencing seizures. Laboratory tests confirm a high parasitemia of Plasmodium falciparum. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cerebral malaria

 

Option C:

 

Cerebral malaria is characterized by seizures, altered consciousness, and high fever in the context of P. falciparum infection. Cerebral malaria manifests as diffuse symmetric encephalopathy characterized by repeated seizures, reduced muscle tone and tendon reflexes Seizures are more common in children (up to 50%) than in adults (10%)

 

Pathogenesis: P. falciparum exhibit unique property of being sequestered inside the brain capillaries due to PfEMP (P. falciparum erythrocyte membrane protein-1), results in plugging of brain capillaries leading to vascular occlusion and cerebral anoxia

 

Laboratory diagnosis: Peripheral blood smear examination is the gold standard method to identify P. falciparum (Banana-shaped gametocytes); Quantitative buffy coat examination and Rapid diagnostic tests (ICT detecting P. falciparum specific HRP-II antigen).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Viral encephalitis – Although presenting with similar neurological symptoms, the presence of high P. falciparum parasitemia makes cerebral malaria more likely.

 

Option B. Bacterial meningitis – Meningitis typically presents with neck stiffness, photophobia, and might not coincide with P. falciparum parasitemia.

 

Option D. Heat stroke – While it can cause altered mental status and high body temperature, it does not explain the high parasitemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebral malaria, linked to P. falciparum infection, is marked by seizures, altered consciousness, and high fever. It involves the sequestration of parasitized RBCs in brain capillaries, causing vascular occlusion and cerebral anoxia. This condition, more common in children, can lead to encephalopathy, retinal hemorrhages, and a high mortality rate. Diagnosis is typically made through peripheral blood smear examination, revealing characteristic P. falciparum forms. 

 

Ref: Paniker’s parasitology 7/e p77, Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Parasitology 1/e p100, 2/e p78

questions.text: A patient with a history of handling rose bushes presents with a nodular lesion on the hand that ulcerated over time. Culture of the lesion grows a fungus that, when stained and examined under a microscope, shows elongated yeast cells resembling cigars. Which of the following diseases is associated with this microscopic finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sporotrichosis

 

Option B:

 

Sporotrichosis, caused by Sporothrix schenckii, is commonly associated with gardening and handling of thorny plants. It is characterized microscopically by the presence of elongated yeast cells that resemble cigars, known as "cigar bodies."

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cryptococcosis is characterized by spherical yeast cells with a thick capsule, which can be visualized using India ink staining.

 

Option C. Histoplasmosis presents with small intracellular yeasts within macrophages, not cigar-shaped bodies.

 

Option D. Aspergillosis is typically associated with septate hyphae that branch at 45-degree angles, not cigar-shaped yeast cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

"Cigar body" morphology of Sporothrix schenckii in tissue samples is important for differentiating it from other fungal infections.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p561, 2/e p585, Jagdish Chander 3/e p163

choices.text: It closely mimics tuberculosis in the early stages.
The infectious form is the mycelial form.
Person-to-person transmission occurs via droplet infection.

questions.text: A 50-year-old HIV-positive man presents with persistent fever, significant weight loss, and abdominal discomfort. He recently visited the Western Ghats during the monsoon season. Examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory tests show pancytopenia, and a bone marrow biopsy reveals macrophages filled with multiple small budding yeasts. What is the most accurate statement regarding his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The infectious form is the mycelial form.

 

Option C:

 

Histoplasmosis, also known as Darling's disease, is caused by the dimorphic fungus Histoplasma capsulatum, which has three biovars:

 

  • H. capsulatum var. capsulatum: Causes classical histoplasmosis, the most common type.
  • H. capsulatum var. duboisii: Causes African histoplasmosis, often affecting skin and bones.
  • H. capsulatum var. farciminosum: Causes epizootic histoplasmosis in horses and mules.

 

Epidemiology: Endemic in the USA, especially the Ohio and lower Mississippi River valleys. Frequently reported in West Bengal, India, along the Ganga River. 

 

Reservoir: Humid, acidic soil with bird or bat droppings.

 

Transmission: Inhalation of contaminated spores.

 

Clinical Manifestations: Most common form is pulmonary histoplasmosis, ranging from mild flu-like illness to chronic cavitary histoplasmosis. Mucocutaneous oral lesions are particularly seen in Indian patients. Disseminated histoplasmosis occurs in individuals with low cell-mediated immunity, like HIV patients.

 

Laboratory Diagnosis:

 

  • Histopathological staining shows tiny oval yeast cells with narrow-based budding.
  • Culture at 25°C yields mycelial colonies; at 37°C, it converts to yeast form. Antibodies detectable by CFT and immunodiffusion test.
  • Skin tests can indicate delayed-type hypersensitivity.

 

 

Figure: Histoplasma capsulatum. A. 2–4 μm yeast cells with narrow-based budding (Giemsa stain) (arrow showing); B. Mold form, septate thin hyphae with tuberculate macroconidia (arrow showing)

 

Treatment:

 

  • Acute pulmonary and disseminated histoplasmosis: Liposomal amphotericin B.
  • Chronic cavitary pulmonary histoplasmosis: Itraconazole.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. While it can present similarly to tuberculosis, this is not a distinguishing feature of the disease itself.

 

Option B. Culture can be diagnostic if it yields the characteristic organism.

 

Option D. Histoplasmosis is not transmitted from person to person but through inhalation of environmental spores.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Despite being uncommon in India, histoplasmosis can occur, especially in immunocompromised individuals such as those with HIV/AIDS. The mycelial form of Histoplasma capsulatum, found in the environment, is the infectious form and can be contracted from soil, particularly in areas with bird and bat droppings, such as the Western Ghats during the monsoon season when fungal growth is abundant.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p563, 2/e p586, Harrison 18/e p1641
